awd_titl_txt: RII Track-4: NSF: Understanding the Nanoscale Incommensurate Modulated Structure in the Titanium Alloys
awd_abstract_narration:
This grant supports the fundamental research focusing a novel metal designing strategy and promotes the progress of materials science and technology. Metals are widely used structural materials because of their excellent performance under different loading conditions. However, to achieve synergetic combination of high strength and ductility in metals is essential but difficult. This project aims to investigate a new strategy to overcome the strength-ductility tradeoff in titanium (Ti) alloys by forming precipitates with a well-controlled length scale of spatial heterogeneities (i.e., heterogeneous precipitate structure). The project will identify the critical roles of nanostructures in forming the heterogeneous precipitate structure in Ti alloys using the cutting-edge transmission electron microscopy. The fellowship will allow the PI and a graduate student to visit the nation’s premier electron microscopy center, the MIT.nano research facilities at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. The project will enable the PI to establish a long-term collaboration with MIT.nano and new expertise in materials characterization, that will lead to a long-lasting impact on the research capability at University of Nevada, Reno (UNR). The PI will design new electron microscopy and materials science education modules for students at UNR and outreach activities for K-12 students in the Reno community to impact a young generation of learners, especially those from groups traditionally underrepresented in. STEM.

This Research Infrastructure Improvement Track-4 EPSCoR Research Fellows (RII Track-4) project would provide a fellowship to an Assistant Professor and training for graduate student at the University of Nevada Reno (UNR). Utilizing nanostructures is an effective method to tune the size of precipitates in Ti alloys. In this project, the PI will use nanoscale incommensurate modulated structure (NIMS) as an example to identify the correlations between the local structure, composition and heterogeneous precipitate structure related to NIMS in Ti alloys. The goal of this research is to fundamentally understand the NIMS and its influence on the microstructure evolution during thermal treatment in the Ti alloys. Two specific research aims will be pursued: (i) Identifying the relationship between the alloy composition, processing parameter and the formation mechanism of the NIMS in Ti alloys; and (ii) Demonstrating the role of NIMS in ω and α phase precipitation during heat treatment in Ti alloys. The proposed research is built on the collaboration with the world-leading nanostructured materials scientist and the nation’s premier electron microscopy center at Massachusetts Institute of Technology. We will identify the atomic-level structure and composition characterization of NIMS using the aberration-corrected Themis Z G3 S/TEM and demonstrate the influence of NIMS on microstructure evolution pathways in Ti alloys using the DENS Solution Lightning in-situ TEM heating holder. The integration of highly advanced ex- and in-situ characterization tools is essential for an accurate description of these complex phase transformations in Ti alloys. The successful completion of the proposed project will advance the fundamental understanding of the microstructure evolution related to the nanostructures in Ti alloys, that is critical for accelerating the discovery and development of Ti alloys with a new composition and microstructure.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
The aim of this NSF EPSCoR Fellowship Program is to fundamentally understand the formation mechanism of the nanoscale incommensurate modulated structure (NIMS) and its influence on the microstructure evolution during thermal treatment in Ti alloys. In this fellowship program, we visited the nation’s premier electron microscopy center, the MIT.nano research facilities at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology (MIT), and collaborated with world-leading materials scientist in nanostructured material, Prof. Ju Li from MIT, to utilize the aberration-corrected Thermo Fisher Scientific (TFS) Themis Z G3 scanning transmission electron microscope (S/TEM) equipped with Super-XEDS and EMPAD-based 4D-STEM system. Through the visit and collaboration, we identify the structure and composition in the NIMS and their influences on phase transformation during the heat treatment in Ti alloys.

 

Our first part of experimental studies has been focusing on the influence of alloy composition on the formation of nanoscale incommensurate modulated structure (NIMS) in Ti alloys using high-throughput combinatorial manufacturing and characterization methods. The compositionally gradient Ti-Fe sample was prepared using arc-melting technique and the microstructure in the as-casted compositionally gradient Ti-Fe sample was investigated using scanning electron microscopy and transmission electron microscopy. We have found that with the increase of Fe content, the microstructure formed in Ti-Fe compositionally gradient sample changes from athermal ω phase, to the combination of ω phase and NIMS, and to only NIMS. Additionally, in Ti-Fe compositionally gradient sample, no orthorhombic structure O' phase has been characterized, which is different compared with the nanostructures observed in Ti-Mo binary alloy or Ti-Mo-Al ternary alloy. We also verified the above conclusions using ~Ti-10Fe, Ti-20Fe and Ti-33.6Fe fabricated using arc-melting method. We found that in the ~Ti-20%Fe, the additional reflections start to deviate from perfect ω phase reflections, indicating the formation of NIMS rather than athermal ω phase. The atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM imaging shows the slightly deviation of atoms from their perfect BCC lattice sites in the nanoscale local region. Our experiment data has shown clear evidence of structural change in the nanoscale area in different Ti-Fe alloys through atomic-resolution HAADF-STEM imaging.

 

Our second part of experimental study has focused on the influence of aging temperature on the NIMS in Ti-Fe alloys. The Ti-Fe compositionally gradient sample was isothermally aged for different amount of time, and the microstructure was characterized using conventional TEM, aberration-corrected STEM and 4D STEM. Interestingly, our results show that only athermal ω phase formed during rapid cooling of casting process will transform to isothermal ω phase and form coarse cuboidal morphology ωphase particles. If the alloy composition is higher than a critical value, no isothermal ω phase particles were observed to form. Thus, it has not been characterized any diffusion occurs between the parent phase matrix and NIMS, during isothermal aging.

 

The methodologies developed during this project can potentially be applied to investigate other nanostructures in titanium alloys and other alloys. This study would accelerate the understanding of atom shuffle related phase transformations, and expedite the design of novel titanium alloys and other metallic materials by the utilization of nanoscale precipitates.

 


Last Modified: 02/08/2024
Modified by: Yufeng Zheng
